msContents.summary:
This fragmentary palm-leaf manuscript of a Dhāraṇīsaṃgraha is part of a bundle of a few manuscripts (Add.1680.8), all seemingly composed of collections of dhāraṇīs. Three different manuscripts, all from around the 12th-13th century, have been tentatively identified on the basis of the (often deficient) foliation and of the layout (string hole in a square blank space, string hole in a column-like blank space or an alternation of the two). Further research might shed more light on the subdivision of the whole manuscript bundle.
This identified manuscript has 29 folios. The first six folios are foliated by a modern hand in pencil with Arabic numerals, and are only tentatively attributed to the same manuscript as the following folios.

supportDesc.extent: 29 ff. (Two folios are numbered as 17. Folios 7-9, 11, 27, 28, 31 and 34 missing)
supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā numerals, mid-right margin, verso (absent or difficult to read on some folios).
Arabic numerals in pencil, on some folios.
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, in relatively good condition. Most folios are damaged on the margins in different degrees and a number of akṣaras are illegible or missing. All folios are heavily damaged on the upper left margin. Some folios are effaced and difficult to decipher.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 65 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: One string hole. The string hole is approximately in the middle of 2 cm-wide square blank spaces.

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).

change.persName: Gergely Hidas, Daniele Cuneo and Camillo Formigatti.
